Prove it.

* AS-focused ADCs like Varus, Vayne, Trist, etc. are near-guaranteed to hit 2.00 AS by the 30m mark unless they're really behind. I'll use Varus for this, since I have the best experience with him; we'll ignore his Blight on-hit and pretend he forgot how to use abilities, and say he's level 18.
* Say 80% crit from {{item:3031}} {{item:3087}} {{item:3046}}. Toss in {{item:3072}} as his lifesteal item.
* AD will be 150 from items, 104 from base, for a total of 254 AD.
* So 80% of his attacks will crit for 635 damage (we'll ignore armor too for now). That's an average of 558.8 damage per shot. Multiply by 2 for the 2.00 AS, that's 1117.6 damage per second.

That's ignoring damage from abilities, runes, and passives, but also ignoring damage resistance from armor. Obviously the situation's going to change based on who's getting shot, but as it looks, the number's not THAT far from the mark.
Also doesn't take Stattic Shyv proc into account.

Ordinarily I would agree with you, however the "what about" argument applies when one scenario will drastically impact another; in this case a nerf to mages means a default buff to other classes, particularly adcs that do not really rely on mana.  Furthermore, since both classes are in the same game it is a completely valid argument to ask "what about adcs that can simply right click without running out of their 'resource'".  

Mages are not a problem in League of Legends right now.  A mage is not picked in every single game, but an ADC is chosen virtually every game by both teams---sometimes more than one per team.  This should express a fundamental problem with the game when the most dominant class for the last 8 seasons has been relatively untouched, while others receive constant tweaks/nerfs/changes, etc.  

If I said "sure, you'll nerf mages but what about Blue Essence", well, that would be a bad argument, but when one thing directly impacts another, it's valid.
